awd_titl_txt: AGEP EAGER: Exploring Conditions for Systemic Equity Transformation that Advance Women and Minority STEM Faculty
awd_abstract_narration:
The successful post-secondary education of tomorrow's STEM workforce is improved when women and historically underrepresented minority (URM) faculty are hired and promoted in our nation's universities and colleges. While there have been increases in the diversity of academic doctoral positions, the share of women and URM faculty is considerably less than their share in the U.S. population or in the number of undergraduate students enrolled in STEM. Addressing the barriers to STEM faculty careers is accelerated when organizational change initiatives are employed in the post-secondary education setting.  

This exploratory proof-of-concept study is examining which approaches and which types of leaders, in which institutional contexts, are advancing university and college faculty equity projects such as those funded by the NSF's ADVANCE and Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) programs. The project team is creating a toolkit that includes diagnostic rubrics and equity leadership practices checklists that universities and colleges can use to identify pathways to successful faculty diversity initiatives. The project includes pilot testing of the tools with institutions interested in implementing equity reform on their campuses. The study results and project outcomes will enable our nation's universities and colleges to identify key leverage points for systemic equity transformation and the requisite practices, policies, and cultural changes needed for achieving campus equity goals, providing a concrete means to on-board institutions into demonstrated successful equity approaches. 

This award is funded by the AGEP program, which supports the development, implementation and study of models to increase the number of URM faculty in STEM and STEM education research fields. It is also funded by the NSF ADVANCE program, which provides grants to develop systemic approaches to increase the participation of women in academic STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The anticipated outcomes of the project were a suite of tools to inform how university leaders as change agents work to broaden participation in STEM. While workforce participation nationwide has increased, the number of underrepresented STEM faculty members is still lower than the representation of underrepresented undergraduate students in STEM fields. This project aimed to understand successful institutional initiatives and translate the findings into strategies that can be implemented elsewhere.  The work was informed by research on the institutional contexts and the practices of change agents engaged in two types of NSF-funded work: ADVANCE IT awards and AGEP Alliances. The intellectual merit of this project is the identification of productive areas of overlap across institution- and multi-institution STEM faculty broadening participation projects, and of potential areas where cross-pollination may be enhanced by the adoption of successful strategies from one community in another. The approach involved collecting two kinds of information: 1)  interviews with leaders of equity-enhancing projects, including  faculty, staff and administrators, from a variety of institutions that had received funding and 2) quantitative data about the kinds of institutions receiving funding, the demographics of their students and faculty, the kinds of resources they had available, and information about their location. In so doing, the project advances understanding of effective strategies, given an institution's context, for achieving diversity goals in higher education, and of strategies that may be used regardless of the receipt of funding from NSF ADVANCE and/or NSF AGEP. Of especial interest was a consideration of how intersectional theories and methodologies inform ADVANCE and AGEP projects, the events that inspired institutions to take an institutional perspective on change work, the personal and professional networks employed, dynamics among the project personnel and practices to promote team work and collaboration. Institutional context was key, given the need to promote collaboration across various types of institutions to support broadening participation efforts. To address this, the research team constructed a quantitative data set of all projects funded by ADVANCE or AGEP prior to 2019 and conducted interviews with 50 leaders of these projects. 

 The project's quantitative findings illustrate the complexities of broadening participation in various kinds of institutions.  The researchers utilized data from different sources, including the Integrated Postsecondary Data System (IPEDS) and publicly available information from NSF ADVANCE and AGEP awards databases. The project looked at the types of institutions that received funding and found that certain factors, like being a land grant institution, were associated with securing grants for making positive changes. The researchers also found that institutions receiving funding from  both NSF ADVANCE and AGEP saw larger increases in the number of faculty members from groups underserved in STEM. This information can help universities understand how to improve diversity among their faculty.

The project broadens participation via use of the qualitative and quantitative data to develop tools for designing and implementing appropriate institutional change strategies, given different institutional contexts. The qualitative research has been used to develop specific tools to train faculty and other stakeholders on how to lead and implement change projects. These include scripts for interactive theater performances and case studies drawn from themes in the interviews. Interview themes related to intersectional strategies were used to create a case study that was delivered in a pre-conference workshop at the 2023 ADVANCE Equity in STEM Community Convening, Durham, NC, in June. Approximately 100 attendees participated in the workshop. As a result, another workshop was delivered at the University of Central Florida in November 2023.  Further applications will occur as part of an NSF funded conference collaboration with the University of Virginia in June 2024. A script drawn from the compiled interviews has been accepted for publication in an edited collection of interactive theater scripts to be made available and performed by the Tiger-Lilly Collective Theatre group, University of Memphis ADVANCE ASPIRED project.  Future plans include development of a workshop where participants will complete interactive and creative exercises, inspired by the qualitative interview data, to strengthen their broadening participation efforts. The quantitative data are being used to develop conference presentations and articles for peer reviewed publication. Fully triangulating quantitative data and analyses with qualitative data (i.e., analyses of interviews with PIs from IHEs that have received AGEP and/or ADVANCE funding) is still in progress.  The quantitative data have nonetheless provided a wealth of information for the data analyses, enabling project leaders to assist multiple universities in their efforts to develop institutional transformation projects, apply for NSF funding to implement projects, and ultimately receive NSF funding for these projects. 

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2023
Modified by: Jennifer Jackson
